ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Manchester - Page
ai_page.body:
Approval and permission for building work and home improvements

Depending on the work you're doing you might need to get planning permission or building regulation approval, or both.

If you go ahead without permission or approval, you might end up having to put things back to how they were.

Planning permission

You’ll probably need planning permission if you want to:

  • build something new
  • make a major change, like building an extension
  • change the use of your building

We also have specific rules for Manchester that might affect whether you need planning permission. To be sure, contact us to check if you need planning permission.

Building regulation approval

You need building regulation approval to check the work you're doing reaches certain safety and energy efficiency standards.

You probably need building regulation approval for:

  • a new building
  • an extension
  • a loft-conversion
  • alterations to the structure of the building
  • home improvements like a new boiler, radiators, bathroom, fuse box, electric, windows, doors, and roofing 

Check if your work needs building regulation approval on the Local Authority Building Control website.

Once you know you need approval:

  • Apply for planning permission
  • Apply for building regulation approval

ai_business_case.letter:
Recommendation to the CEO from the Web Manager – Usability Expert Perspective

Dear CEO,

Based on recent user feedback and analysis of our online services, I would like to highlight areas where we can enhance service efficiency, improve customer satisfaction, and reduce administrative costs.

Customer Persona & Needs:
Our typical customer, exemplified by David—a 52-year-old council tenant comfortably using smartphones—prefers straightforward, step-by-step online processes without unnecessary complexity. His primary need is to request permission for minor improvements to his flat, such as installing a kitchen or adding a handrail. He also concerns himself with timely updates and clear guidance to avoid misunderstandings or delays.

Key Feedback & Issues:
The customer feedback indicates partial clarity in our current information:
- While the guidance explains when permissions are needed, it lacks explicit instructions on *how* to submit applications online and the associated timelines.
- Customers like David expressed the need for direct links to relevant forms, simplified step-by-step guides, and clear expectations for processing times.
- The absence of such details leads to confusion, potential delays, and increased calls or emails to our support teams, raising costs and straining resources.

Current Page Content:
The existing page includes important information on planning permission and building regulation approval but does not provide:
- Direct, clickable links to online application forms.
- Clear, sequential instructions simplified for laypersons.
- Estimated processing times or instructions on how to receive updates.

Recommendations for Improvements:
1. Incorporate prominent, clickable links to all relevant online forms directly within the guidance text.
2. Develop a concise, step-by-step online application guide tailored to typical requests, utilizing visual cues or infographics to enhance comprehension.
3. Clearly state processing timelines—for example, "Most applications are decided within X weeks"—and specify how users will receive updates (e.g., email notifications).
4. Implement a simple FAQ or troubleshooting section addressing common concerns like delays or submitting additional information.
5. Optimize the page for mobile use, ensuring all links and instructions are easily navigable on smartphones.

Impact on Customer Experience & Cost Savings:
Enhancing clarity and streamlining the application process will:
- Reduce user frustration and reliance on support staff, decreasing operational costs.
- Increase the likelihood of accurate submissions, reducing administrative back-and-forth.
- Boost trust and satisfaction among residents, fostering positive engagement with council services.
- Encourage more residents to use online channels, freeing up resources for complex or high-priority cases.

In conclusion, targeted improvements focusing on clarity, direct navigability, and transparency will significantly benefit our resident experience and deliver cost efficiencies for the council.

Kind regards,

[Name]
Web Manager & Usability Specialist
